revision.text:
{{Short description|none}} <!-- Please do not remove or change this AfD message until the discussion has been closed. --> {{AfDM|page=List of IMAX venues (4th nomination)|year=2024|month=April|day=28|substed=yes|origtag=afdx|help=off}} <!-- End of AfD message, feel free to edit beyond this point --> {{Cleanup rewrite|date=March 2022}} {{Use Canadian English|date=July 2020}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2024}} [[File:IMAX blue logo.svg|thumb|Official logo]] This is a list of [[IMAX]] venues which feature either [[IMAX with Laser]] 4K projectors and/or [[70 mm film#IMAX (15/70)|15/70 mm]] film projectors. Not included are theatres with solely [[2K resolution]] digital [[Xenon arc lamp|xenon]] projectors.
IMAX with Laser locations use one of four types of 4K projector: * GT{{efn|name=fn3|Grand Theatre}} Laser: Dual projector system capable of up to 1.43:1 aspect ratio. * CoLa{{efn|Commercial Laser}}: Single projector, limited to 1.90:1 aspect ratio. * XT: Single projector, limited to 1.90:1 aspect ratio. * Dome Laser: Single projector. Used in dome theatres.<ref>{{cite news |title=Fleet Science Center: A New Digital Era At The Heikoff Giant Dome Theatre |url=https://www.kpbs.org/events/2021/10/29/fleet-science-center-a-new-digital-era-at-the-heikoff-giant-dome-theatre |access-date=12 November 2021 |work=kpbs |agency=kpbs.org |date=29 October 2021}}</ref>
Traditional 15/70 mm IMAX locations use [[70 mm film]] projectors, with the film running through the projector(s) horizontally, each frame being 15 [[film perforations|perforations]] wide. 3D presentations are shown using two projectors and either [[linear polarized]] or [[Active shutter 3D system|LCD shutter]] glasses. These locations are capable of displaying [[aspect ratios]] of up to 1.43:1.
IMAX 15/70 mm locations use one of five types of film projectors: * GT:{{efn|name=fn3}} IMAX 15/70 mm 2D film projector. * GT3D: IMAX 15/70 mm 3D film projector, dual rotor. * SR: IMAX 15/70 mm 3D film projector{{efn|Usually comes as 2 separate SR projectors synched for 3D or used alternatively when a changeover is involved to play longer films when fully upgraded QTRU is not present. If only one is available, projection is limited to 2D}}, small rotor. * GT Dome: IMAX 15/70 mm 2D dome film projector. * SR Dome: IMAX 15/70 mm 2D dome film projector, small rotor.
Some theatres with legacy 1.43:1 screens have single laser projectors or digital projectors; these installations are restricted to projecting at a maximum of 1.90:1.
Dome theatres may indicate one or two screen sizes. The first (or only) number indicates the screen diameter. The second number (if present) indicates the screen surface width.

==Oceania== {| class="wikitable sortable" !Country !City !Location Name !Screen Aspect Ratio (AR) !Digital Projector !Maximum AR for digital projection !Film Projector !Screen dimensions !Commercial films shown? |- | rowspan="2" |Australia |[[Melbourne]] |IMAX, Melbourne Museum<ref>{{Cite web |date=8 October 2023 |title=IMAX, Melbourne Museum |url=https://www.imax.com/theatre/imax-melbourne-museum |access-date=4 February 2024 |website=www.imax.com |language=en}}</ref> |1.43:1 |IMAX GT Laser |1.43:1 |IMAX GT3D 15/70 mm, (2D Only)<ref>Single Installed Platter (No 3D).
Our 1570 projector is a dual rotor 3D GT projector - however when we re-instated the projector in 2017 after Laser projectors were already in place, we didn't have enough space to be able to install the 2 x platters required to run films in 3D. As Nolan always shoots for 2D - and with limited film prints available, we are now only able to screen 1570 films in 2D.
Hope this answers your questions
Lauren (she/her)
Duty Manager
